div.head: Report:
div.p: In continuation of our research on the preparation of polymer blends via in-situ polymerisation of a reactive solvent [1], we report results of in-situ wide-angle X-ray diffraction (WAXD) experiments, performed on station ID1 l-BL2, in order to study the phase behaviour of syndiotactic polystyrene (sPS) solutions. This is one of the important conditions to successfully apply the processing technique with reactive solvents in order to select the proper concentration and temperature for in-situ polymerisation. Two solvents were used: benzylmethacrylate (BzMA) and cyclohexylmethacrylate (CHMA). Upon quenching sPS solutions gel formation occurs. In these gels sPS adopts a helical conformation which is stabilised by the solvent molecules, in fact compound formation occurs. From the combined experimental data it was concluded that two different structural modifications exist within the solvent-included helical &phase, respectively the 6' phase in which the solvent molecules are intercalated and ordered between the phenyl rings of sPS, and a 8' phase where the solvent ordering is lost [2]. The so-called y-phase, the solventfree helical phase, was not observed in our studies. The transformation from the helical (6") phase to the planar zigzag (p) phase occurs via melting and recrystallisation. In figures la and lb, some illustrative results of heating runs of the 40 wt% sPS/BzMA and 40 wt% sPS/CHMA systems are depicted, respectively. In figure 2, the results from in-situ WAXD Figure 1.

figure.figDesc: Figure 1. WAXD results obtained during a heating run from 20째C to 230째C at S"C/min of quenched samples a) 40 wt% sPS/BzMA b) 40 wt% sPS/CHMA.
